data.title: Film Review - Operation Mincemeat
data.meta_description: Simon Dillon reviews John Madden's adaptation of Ben Macintyre's fact-based book about a British military intelligence deception during World War II.
data.text:
Operation Mincemeat refers to a real-life British World War II intelligence operation. It concerned a drowned royal marine, whose parachute had failed to open, washing up on Spanish shores, carrying a briefcase containing classified documents. Said documents referred to British military plans to attack Greece rather than Sicily, in an attempt to regain a foothold in Europe, circa 1943. The documents were a ruse, intended to trick Hitler into moving troops to Greece, thus ensuring an easier invasion of Sicily.

This bold operation was a hugely audacious gamble on the part of the British. It’s therefore a shame that John Madden’s film, based on Ben Macintyre’s book, is considerably less audacious as a piece of cinema. Not that it’s a bad film by any means. It’s competently assembled with a fine cast on good form that holds viewer interest throughout. But the low-key dramatics fail to catch fire as they ought.

The primary brains championing Operation Mincemeat are Ewen Montagu (Colin Firth) and Charles Cholmondeley (Matthew Macfadyen). Their recommendations are treated with snooty disdain by Admiral John Godfrey (Jason Isaacs), but when…
